sourceDesc.ab: Translation of 淮南子 into English.

p.seg: and all embraced their virtue.
In ancient times, there were those who wore helmets and rolled up their sleeves to rule the world.
Their virtue was to give life and not kill,
to give and not take.
The world did not oppose their rule,
During this time,
yin and yang were in harmony,
wind and rain came in season,
and all things flourished.
The nests of crows and magpies could be reached down and touched,
and birds and beasts could be tamed and followed.
Was it necessary to wear elaborate clothes and wide belts,
with curved collars and trailing hats?
In ancient times, people lived in marshes and caves.
In winter, they could not withstand the frost, snow, fog, and dew.
In summer, they could not withstand the heat, humidity, and insects.
The sages then built houses for them with earth and wood,
with roofs above and walls below,
to shelter them from wind and rain,
and to protect them from cold and heat.
And the people were at peace.
When Bo Yu first made clothes,
he twisted hemp fibers
and threaded them by hand,
and the result was like a net.
Later generations invented looms and spinning wheels to make clothing more efficient,
and people were able to cover their bodies and protect themselves from the cold.
Later generations invented plows, hoes, axes, and pulleys,
In ancient times, people plowed with sharpened sticks,
weeded by hand,
chopped wood with wooden hooks,
and carried water in jars.
The people labored hard, but their gains were meager.
making work easier and more productive.
In ancient times, large rivers and valleys
blocked roads
and hindered travel.
So people made boats from hollowed-out logs and planks,
and facilitating the exchange of goods
enabling transportation across water
between regions.
To travel a thousand miles on foot,
carrying burdens on one's shoulders, is arduous.
Therefore, people invented wheeled vehicles,
harnessed horses and oxen,
enabling them to travel long distances without exhaustion.
Birds of prey and wild beasts harmed people, and there was no way to defend against them.
So people invented metal casting and forging,
creating weapons
that could protect them from these threats.
Therefore, when people face difficulties, they seek solutions;
when they encounter problems, they create tools.
Each person uses their knowledge
to remove harm
and pursue benefits.
Old ways cannot always be followed,
and tools cannot remain unchanged.
Thus, the laws and regulations of ancient kings must also evolve.
According to ancient customs,
marriage proposals were not initiated by the groom's family.
Shun married without informing his parents,
which was not in accordance with the rites.
The eldest son should be the heir.
King Wen bypassed Bo Yikao and chose Wu as his successor,
which was not in accordance with the established rules.
The rites dictate that one should marry at thirty.
King Wen fathered King Wu at fifteen,
which was not in accordance with the law.
The Xia placed the coffin on the eastern steps,
the Shang placed it between the pillars,
and the Zhou placed it on the western steps.
These are the differences in funeral rites.
The Youyu clan used earthenware coffins,
the Xia dynasty used brick chambers,
the Shang dynasty used wooden outer coffins,
and the Zhou dynasty used screens placed against the wall.
These are the differences in burial practices.
The Xia dynasty held sacrifices in the dark,
the Shang dynasty held sacrifices in the light,
and the Zhou dynasty held sacrifices at sunrise.
These are the differences in sacrificial practices.
Yao had the "Great Chapter,"
Shun had the "Nine Shao,"
Yu had the "Great Xia,"
Tang had the "Great Hu,"
and the Zhou had the "Martial Elephant."
These are the differences in music.
Therefore, the Five Emperors had different ways but their virtue covered the world,
and the Three Kings had different practices but their names were passed down to later generations.
These were all due to adapting rites and music to the changing times.
It is like Shi Kuang adjusting the strings of his zither.
There is no fixed measurement for how much he moves them up or down,
yet every note is perfectly in tune.
Therefore, those who understand the principles of rites and music can create them.
Their words have a basis and a core,
and they know the boundaries within which rules and regulations operate.
Duke Zhao of Lu had a loving mother and cherished her.
When she died, he wore a mourning cap made of white silk for her,
thus establishing the mourning attire for a loving mother.
The Marquis of Yang killed the Marquis of Liao and took his wife.
Therefore, the grand banquet abolished the ritual of the wife's participation.
The institutions of the former kings,
if unsuitable, should be abolished;
the practices of later generations,
if good, should be adopted.
Therefore, rites and music have never been constant.
Therefore, the sages created rites and music,
but they were not bound by them.
There are constants in governing a state,
but benefiting the people is fundamental.
Governance and education have their principles,
but good conduct is paramount.
If it benefits the people,
there is no need to follow ancient practices.
If it is effective in dealing with matters,
there is no need to adhere to old ways.
The decline of Xia and Shang
was due to their failure to adapt their laws and perished.
The rise of the Three Dynasties
was due to their not imitating each other and thus becoming kings.
Therefore, the sage's laws change with the times,
and rites evolve with customs.
Clothing and tools are each convenient for their use,
and laws and decrees are each adapted to their circumstances.
Therefore, changing ancient ways cannot be condemned,
and following customs is not always sufficient.
Hundreds of rivers have different sources but all flow to the sea;
hundreds of schools have different teachings but all aim for good governance.
The decline of the royal way led to the creation of the Shijing (Classic of Poetry);
the fall of the Zhou dynasty and the collapse of rites and righteousness
led to the creation of the Chunqiu (Spring and Autumn Annals)
The Shijing and Chunqiu are beautiful works of learning,
but they were created in times of decline.
Confucian scholars follow them to teach the world,
but how can they compare to the flourishing Three Dynasties?
To consider the Shijing and Chunqiu as the ancient way and value them
is to ignore the time before they were created.
The way in its incomplete form
is not as good as the way in its complete form.
Reciting the ancient kings' writings
is not as good as hearing their words;
hearing their words
is not as good as understanding the reasons behind their words.
Those who understand the reasons behind the words
cannot express them in words.
Therefore, the way that can be spoken of
is not the constant way.
When the Duke of Zhou served King Wen,
he did not act arbitrarily,
nor did he make decisions on his own.
He carried himself as if he could not bear the weight of his clothes,
and spoke as if the words would not come out of his mouth.
He was respectful and attentive to King Wen,
always deferential,
as if he were incapable
and afraid of making mistakes.
He can truly be called a filial son.
After King Wu's death,
King Cheng was young,
and the Duke of Zhou continued the work of Kings Wen and Wu.
He ascended the throne as regent,
managed the affairs of the world,
quelled the rebellions of the barbarians,
punished the crimes of Guan and Cai,
received the feudal lords at court,
and made decisions on rewards and punishments
without consulting anyone.
His authority shook the heavens and the earth,
and his reputation spread throughout the land.
He can truly be called a capable warrior.
When King Cheng came of age,
the Duke of Zhou returned the throne and power,
faced north and pledged his loyalty as a subject.
He acted only after receiving permission,
and proceeded only after confirmation.
He had no intention of acting arbitrarily,
nor did he show any arrogance.
He can truly be called a capable minister.
Therefore, the reason why one person can change three times
is to adapt to the times.
What's more, when rulers change frequently
and countries change rulers frequently,
people use their positions
to express their likes and dislikes,
and use their power to satisfy their desires.
If they want to use one set of rites
and one set of laws
to respond to the occasional changes of the times,
it is clear that they cannot achieve the right balance.
Therefore, what the sage follows is called the Way,
and what the sage does is called action.
The Way is like metal and stone,
once tuned, it does not change;
action is like the zither and the se,
each performance requires a different tuning.
Therefore, laws, systems, rites, and righteousness
but not the essence of governance itself.
are the tools of governance,
Therefore, benevolence is the guiding principle,
and righteousness is the standard.
These are the eternal and unchanging values.
As for examining people's talents
and adjusting their roles according to the times,
even daily changes are acceptable.
How can there be unchanging laws in the world?
When actions are appropriate to the times,
in accordance with human nature,
harmonious with heaven and earth,
and auspicious for the spirits,
then good governance can be achieved.
In ancient times, the people were pure and simple,
both men and women were innocent and childlike.
Therefore, it was easy to transform them through governance and education,
and their customs were easily changed.
In the present age, virtue has declined,
and the customs of the people have become increasingly superficial.
To try to govern the already corrupted people
with the methods used for the innocent and childlike
is like trying to control a wild horse without a bit, bridle, whip, or armor.
In the past,
Shennong had no laws or decrees, yet the people followed him.
Tang and Yu had laws and decrees but no punishments.
The Xia dynasty did not break their promises,
the Shang people made oaths,
and the Zhou people made covenants.
In today's world,
people are shameless and disrespectful,
greedy and shameless.
If one tries to govern them with the Way of Shennong,
chaos will surely ensue.
Bo Chengzi Gao resigned from his position as a feudal lord and became a farmer,
and the world praised him for it.
People nowadays
resign from office and live in seclusion,
becoming subordinate to the local community.
How can this be compared to the past?
In ancient times,
weapons were limited to bows and swords.
Arrows had soft tips and could not pierce armor,
and halberds were not sharp enough to stab.
In later times, weapons
included battering rams for attacking,
shields and curtains for defense,
repeating crossbows for shooting,
and chariots for battle.
In ancient warfare,
they did not kill children
or the elderly.
What was considered righteous in ancient times
is now laughed at.
What was considered honorable in ancient times
is now considered shameful.
What was considered good governance in ancient times
is now considered chaos.
Shennong and Fuxi did not impose rewards or punishments, yet the people did not commit wrongdoing.
However, those who establish governments cannot abolish laws and still govern the people.
Shun wielded weapons and subdued the Miao tribe,
yet those who engage in warfare cannot lay down their arms and control the violent and unruly.
From this, we can see
that laws and regulations
are used to assess the customs of the people and to regulate urgency;
tools and weapons
are created to adapt to the changing times and to suit the circumstances.
The sage creates laws, and all things are regulated by them;
the virtuous establish rites, and the unworthy are constrained by them.
Those who are bound by laws
cannot be expected to undertake great endeavors;
those who are confined by rites
Those whose ears cannot distinguish between clear and turbid sounds
cannot be expected to adapt to change.
cannot be asked to tune instruments;
those whose minds do not understand the sources of order and chaos
cannot be asked to create laws and regulations.
One must have exceptional hearing
and exceptional vision
to be able to master the Way and act accordingly.
The Shang changed the Xia,
the Zhou changed the Shang,
and the Spring and Autumn period changed the Zhou.
The rites of the Three Dynasties were different,
so which antiquity should we follow?
The great men create, and the disciples follow.
Those who know the origin of law and governance
will adapt to the times;
those who do not understand the source of law and governance
will eventually fall into chaos even if they follow ancient practices.
[will eventually fall into chaos]
The laws and regulations of today's world change with the times,
and rites and righteousness change with customs.
Scholars follow the old ways and adhere to tradition,
believing that without them, there can be no good governance.
This is like holding a square handle
It is difficult to achieve a proper fit and a firm grip.
and trying to fit it into a round hole.
The Confucians and Mohists today praise the Three Dynasties and the Kings Wen and Wu,
but they do not follow their ways.
They criticize the present age but do not change their ways.
They preach what they do not practice
but act contrary to it.
They praise what they consider right
Therefore, they spend their days worrying but do not contribute to good governance,
and they exhaust themselves physically and mentally but do not benefit their rulers.
Nowadays, painters love to depict ghosts and demons
but dislike painting dogs and horses.
Why is this?
Ghosts and demons are rarely seen,
while dogs and horses can be seen every day.
To save a country from danger and restore order requires wisdom;
but to simply praise the past,
even a fool can do it.
Therefore, the sage kings do not implement laws that are not practical,
nor do they listen to words that are not proven.
The greatest of the qi of heaven and earth
is harmony.
Harmony
means the balance of yin and yang,
the division of day and night,
and the generation of living things.
Life begins at the spring equinox
and matures at the autumn equinox.
Both life and maturity
require the essence of harmony.
Therefore, the way of the sage
is lenient yet respectful,
strict yet gentle,
flexible yet upright,
and forceful yet benevolent.
Too much rigidity leads to breaking,
too much flexibility leads to bending.
The sage maintains a balance between rigidity and flexibility,
thus attaining the essence of the Way.
An accumulation of yin leads to stagnation,
an accumulation of yang leads to dissipation.
Only when yin and yang interact
can harmony be achieved.
The rope, as a measuring tool,
can be coiled and carried,
or stretched out
to be straight and long.
Therefore, the sage uses it as a metaphor for the body.
What can be long without being broad,
short without being limited,
straight without being rigid,
and enduring without being forgotten?
Only the rope!
Therefore, excessive kindness leads to weakness,
and weakness leads to a lack of authority;
excessive strictness leads to harshness,
and harshness leads to disharmony;
excessive love leads to indulgence,
and indulgence leads to disorder;
excessive punishment leads to cruelty,
and cruelty leads to alienation.
In the past,
Duke Jian of Qi relinquished the power of the state
and solely relied on his ministers and generals.
They seized power
and formed cliques,
leading to the obstruction of justice.
This allowed Chen Chengchang and Chi Yi Zipi to successfully stage a coup.
The fact that the Lu family's ancestral sacrifices were cut off and the Chen family took over the state
was a result of Duke Jian's weakness and indecisiveness.
Zichan was resolute and fond of punishment.
When it came to punishment,
he was strict and showed no mercy.
One of his attendants broke a bow
and, fearing punishment and execution,
took advantage of a mad dog scare to kill Zichan.
This was a consequence of Zichan's harshness and severity.
Those who do not understand the Way,
seeing the weak and timid being bullied,
become proud of being resolute and determined;
seeing the resolute and determined perish,
they become proud of being weak and timid.
This is because they have no fundamental principle within themselves,
and their perceptions are scattered and contradictory.
Therefore, they spend their entire lives without a fixed direction.
It is like someone who does not understand music trying to sing.
If they sing low, their voice is muffled and lacks modulation;
if they sing high, their voice is shrill and out of tune.
But when it comes to the singing of Han E, Qin Qing, Xue Tan,
Hou Tong, and Man Sheng,
their emotions are expressed through their voices,
accumulating within
and overflowing into sound.
Then, their voices are all in accordance with the musical scale
and resonate with the human heart.
Why is this so?
Because they have a fundamental principle within themselves to determine the clarity and turbidity of their voices, and they are not influenced by external factors but create their own standards.
Now, a blind person walking on the road
will go left if told to go left,
and right if told to go right.
If they meet a gentleman, they may change their path;
if they meet a villain, they may fall into a ditch.
Why is this?
Because their eyes cannot perceive things.
Therefore, the state of Wei employed both Lou Huan and Wu Qi, but lost the West River region.
King Min of Qi relied solely on Nao Chi and died in the Eastern Temple.
They lacked the skill to control them.
King Wen of Zhou employed both Lü Wang and Duke of Zhou and became king.
King Zhuang of Chu relied solely on Sunshu Ao and became a hegemon.
They had the skill to control them.
Confucius established the use of stringed instruments, singing, drumming, and dancing for music,
bowing and yielding for rituals,
and elaborate funerals and prolonged mourning for the deceased.
However, Mozi criticized these practices.
Mozi advocated for universal love and the elevation of the worthy,
as well as belief in ghosts and spirits and the rejection of fatalism.
However, Yang Zhu criticized these ideas.
Yang Zhu advocated for preserving one's true nature
However, Mencius criticized this philosophy.
People's preferences and choices differ,
and not being burdened by material possessions.
and each has their own understanding.
Therefore, right and wrong have their place.
When applied correctly, there is no wrong;
when applied incorrectly, there is no right.
The people of Danxue, Taimeng, Fanzhong, Kongtong, Daxia, Beihu, Qigong, and Xiugu
have different notions of right and wrong,
and their customs are opposite to each other.
Yet, rulers and subjects, superiors and inferiors,
husbands and wives, fathers and sons,
all have ways to interact with each other.
What is right here
is not necessarily right there;
what is wrong here i
s not necessarily wrong there.
It is like axes, chisels, hammers, and awls, each having its own specific use.
During the time of Yu,
he governed by listening to the five tones.
He hung bells, drums, chimes, and other instruments,
and set up a drum
to await the arrival of scholars from all directions.
He issued a decree saying,
"Those who teach me the Way should beat the drum,
those who instruct me in righteousness should strike the bell,
those who report matters to me should shake the rattle,
those who speak to me of their worries should strike the chime,
and those who have lawsuits should shake the clapper."
At this time,
he would rise ten times during a meal
and hold his hair three times while washing,
all for the sake of caring for the people of the world.
If, in doing so, one cannot achieve goodness and loyalty,
then they lack talent.
In the time of the Qin dynasty,
they built tall terraces and pavilions,
vast gardens and parks,
and long roads for chariots.
They cast bronze statues,
sent people to distant garrisons,
collected grain and hay,
taxed every household,
and delivered the revenue to the Shao Fu (treasury).
Strong men
were sent west to Lintao and Didao,
east to Kuaiji and Fushi,
south to Yuzhang and Guilin,
and north to Feihou and Yangyuan.
The roads were filled with the dead, so many that they were measured by ditches.
At this time,
those who offered loyal advice were considered unlucky,
and those who spoke of benevolence and righteousness were considered mad.
When it came to the time of the Exalted Emperor (Gaozu of Han),
he revived the fallen and continued the broken lineage,
upholding the great righteousness of the world.
He personally rolled up his sleeves, grasped weapons,
and sought the mandate of heaven for the people.
At this time,
the heroes and talents of the world were exposed to the wilderness,
facing arrows and stones in front
and falling into ravines behind.
They emerged from a hundred deaths with a single life,
striving for the power of the world,
exerting their martial prowess and sincerity
to determine their fate in a single day.
At this time,
those who wore fine clothes and wide belts and spoke of Confucianism and Mohism
were considered unworthy.
When the rebellion was quelled
and peace was restored within the realm,
the emperor continued the legacy of culture,
established military achievements,
followed the traditions of the Son of Heaven,
and created the crown of the Liu family.
He gathered Confucian and Mohist scholars from Zou and Lu,
promoted the teachings of the ancient sages,
held high the banner of the emperor,
rode on the grand avenue,
raised the nine banners,
struck the great bell,
beat the resounding drum,
played the "Xianchi" music,
and raised the shield and axe.
At this time,
those who established themselves through martial prowess were viewed with suspicion.
civil and military power alternated as dominant and subordinate,
each having its time of use.
Within a single generation,
In the present age, those who pursue martial arts reject culture,
and those who pursue culture reject martial arts.
They criticize each other,
not understanding the appropriate use for each in different times.
This is like seeing a single finger in a corner
and not knowing the vastness of the eight directions.
Therefore, facing east,
one cannot see the western wall;
facing south,
one cannot see the north.
Only those who have no fixed direction
can be said to be unobstructed in all directions.
The reason why a state exists
is morality.
The reason why a family perishes
is the blockage of principle.
Yao did not have a hundred households' town,
Shun did not have land to plant an awl,
yet they possessed the world.
Yu did not have ten followers,
Tang did not have seven li of territory,
yet they became kings of the feudal lords
When King Wen was in Qi and Zhou,
the area was no more than a hundred li,
yet he was established as the Son of Heaven
because he had the kingly way.
At the height of Xia Jie and Yin Zhou,
wherever people went,
wherever boats and carts traveled,
there were counties and counties,
but they died at the hands of others
and were laughed at by the world
because they had the appearance of perishing.
Therefore, the sage sees the transformation and observes its signs.
Virtue has prosperity and decline,
and the wind first sprouts. [HERE THE SYSTEM IS NOT TRYING! CH]
Therefore, those who obtain the kingly way,
though small, will surely become great;
those who have the appearance of perishing,
though successful, will surely fail.
When Xia was about to perish,
the grand historian Zhong Gu first fled to Shang,
and three years later Jie perished.
When Yin was about to be defeated,
the grand historian Xiang Yi first returned to King Wen,
and after a full year, Zhou perished.
Therefore, the sage's view of the traces of survival and death,
the juncture of success and failure,
is not the wilderness of Mingtiao,
the day of Jiazi.
Now, those who say that the strong win will measure the land and count the people,
and those who are rich will measure the grain and weigh the gold.
If this is the case,
then the monarch of ten thousand chariots will not be a hegemon,
and the state of a thousand chariots will not be defeated.
The traces of survival and death
are so easy to know,
even a foolish man or woman can discuss them.
Zhao Xiangzi dominated with the city of Jinyang,
Zhi Bo was captured with the land of the three Jins;
King Min perished with the great Qi,
Tian Dan made contributions with Jimo.
Therefore, when a country perishes,
even if it is big, it is not enough to rely on;
when the Tao is practiced,
even if it is small, it cannot be taken lightly.
From this point of view,
existence depends on the Tao and not on greatness,
and perishing depends on losing the Tao and not on smallness.
The Book of Songs says,
"Then look to the west,
this is only with the house."
It means leaving Yin and moving to Zhou.
Therefore, the rulers of chaotic countries
strive to expand their territory but not to strive for benevolence and righteousness,
strive to elevate their positions but not to strive for morality,
thus abandoning the reason for their existence
and creating the reason for their demise.
Therefore, Jie was imprisoned in Jiaomen,
and could not deny what he did,
and regretted not killing Tang in Xiatai;
Zhou was imprisoned in Xuanshi,
and did not repent of his mistakes,
and regretted not killing King Wen in Youli.
The two monarchs were in a position of strength and power,
and practiced the way of benevolence and righteousness.
Tang and Wu could not save their sins,
so what conspiracy did they dare to worry about?
If the light of the three lights is disturbed above,
and the hearts of the ten thousand people are lost below,
who is insignificant to Tang and Wu,
who cannot be taken away?
Now, if you do not examine what is in yourself,
but instead prepare for it in others,
the world is not a Tang and Wu,
if you kill one person,
there will surely be successors.
Moreover, the reason why Tang and Wu were able to become kings in a small and weak position
was because they had the Tao;
the reason why Jie and Zhou were in a strong and powerful position and were eventually taken away
was because they did not have the Tao.
Now, if you do not practice the way of the king,
but instead increase the reason for your own deprivation,
this is the way to perish.
After King Wu conquered Yin,
he wanted to build a palace on the Five Elements Mountain.
The Duke of Zhou said,
"No!
The Five Elements Mountain
is a naturally fortified and dangerous place.
If our virtue can cover it,
then those who pay tribute from all over the world will return.
If we have violent and chaotic behavior,
then it will be difficult for the world to attack us."
This is why it has not been taken away for thirty-six generations.
The Duke of Zhou can be said to be able to hold full.
In ancient times,
the Book of Zhou said:
"What the superior says,
the subordinate uses;
what the subordinate says,
the superior uses.
What the superior says
is constant;
what the subordinate says
is expedient."
This is the art of survival and demise.
Only the sage can know expediency.
To speak and be trustworthy,
to promise and fulfill,
is the highest conduct in the world.
Zhi Gong's father stole a sheep and his son testified against him;
Wei Sheng promised to meet a woman and died waiting for her.
To be upright and testify against one's father,
to be trustworthy and die for a woman,
even though there is uprightness and trustworthiness,
who can value it!
To disobey the orders of the three armies
is a great mistake.
Duke Mu of Qin raised an army to attack Zheng,
passing through Zhou and heading east.
Xian Gao, a merchant from Zheng, was going west to sell cattle
and encountered the Qin army between Zhou and Zheng.
He then falsely claimed an order from the Duke of Zheng,
rewarded them with twelve cattle, entertained the Qin army,
and made them retreat,
thus preserving the state of Zheng.
Therefore, when things reach a certain point,
trustworthiness can become a mistake,
and deception can become a merit.
What is meant by "losing propriety but achieving great merit?"
In the past, King Gong of Chu fought against Duke Li of Jin at Yinling.
Lü Qi shot King Gong,
hit his eye, and captured him.
Pan Ang, Yang Youji, Huang Shuaiwei, and Gongsun Bing together usurped him.
King Gong was afraid and lost his composure.
Huang Shuaiwei raised his foot and kicked his body,
and King Gong woke up.
Angry at his loss of composure,
he roused himself and stood up,
and the four ministers carried him away.
In the past, Cang Wu Rao married a beautiful wife
and gave her to his brother.
This is what is called loyalty and love but cannot be practiced.
Therefore, the sage discusses the right and wrong of things,
and adapts to them with flexibility,
without a fixed pattern,
sometimes bending and sometimes stretching.
To be weak and soft like cattails and reeds
is not to be cowardly;
to be strong and resolute,
with aspirations soaring to the blue clouds,
is not to be arrogant;
it is to adapt to the changing circumstances.
The interaction between ruler and minister
involves bowing and kneeling
to show respect and courtesy.
But when faced with danger,
one may raise a foot to kick the other's body,
and no one in the world can criticize this.
Therefore, where loyalty lies,
propriety is not enough to challenge it.
A filial son serves his parents
with a gentle face and humble body,
holding their belts and carrying their shoes.
But when they are drowning,
he grabs their hair and pulls them out,
not daring to be arrogant or insulting,
but to save their lives.
Therefore, when drowning, one grabs their father,
and when praying, one addresses the ruler by name.
The situation demands it.
This is where expediency comes into play.
Therefore, Confucius said:
"One can study together,
but one cannot yet walk the right path with them.
One can walk the right path with them,
but one cannot yet establish themselves.
One can establish themselves,
but one cannot yet exercise discretion with them."
Discretion
is something that only the sage can see.
Therefore, those who first oppose and then agree
are said to know discretion;
those who first agree and then disagree
are said to not know discretion.
Those who do not know discretion
turn good into evil.
Therefore, propriety
is the flower of substance and the embellishment of falsehood.
In times of sudden urgency and distress,
it is of no use.
Therefore, the sage interacts with the world through culture,
but acts according to the practical needs of the situation.
They do not adhere to a single path,
nor do they become rigid and unchanging.
Therefore, they fail in few things and succeed in many,
and their orders are carried out throughout the world without anyone being able to criticize them.
The orangutan knows the past but not the future,
the wild swan knows the future but not the past;
this is the difference between long and short.

Therefore, Chang Hong knew the ways of heaven but not human affairs,
Su Qin knew strategies but not fortune and misfortune,
Xu Yanwang knew benevolence and righteousness but not the right time,

The sage is different.
They assess the world
and act accordingly,
adapting their strategies to the circumstances.
Therefore, they can expand their influence throughout the world without being excessive,
and they can keep it within the ordinary without being restricted.
If the world is in chaos,

the powerful fight each other,

armor is infested with lice,

If the world is peaceful,

Therefore, the sage

They move and rest according to the time,
achieve success by utilizing resources,
know the opposite when things move,

They adapt to transformations
and respond to movements,
thus they can act throughout their lives without encountering difficulties.
Therefore, there are things that can be done but not spoken of,
things that can be spoken of but not done,

What is meant by "things that can be done but not spoken of"

"things that are easy to do but difficult to accomplish"
are tasks;
"things that are difficult to accomplish but easy to fail"

These four strategies

To bend an inch and extend a foot,
the sage does it;
to bend a little for a greater good,
the noble person does it.
The Duke of Zhou had the burden of killing his brother,
Duke Huan of Qi had the reputation of fighting for the throne,

If we cover up people's great merits because of their small faults,

Therefore, a blemish in the eye

so it should not be cauterized;
a disease in the throat

so it should not be cut open.
The mounds on the riverbank
are countless,
yet they are considered easy to cross.
The water stirs up waves,
with high and low points facing each other,
yet the difference is considered normal,

If Cao Zi had not cared about the consequences,
had not turned back,
and had cut his throat in the battlefield,
he would have been a defeated general for the rest of his life.
However, Cao Zi was not ashamed of his defeat,
but ashamed to die without merit.
At the Covenant of Ke,
he drew a three-foot blade

He recovered in one morning what he had lost in three battles,
his bravery was known throughout the world,
and he established merit in the state of Lu.

he fled and escaped,

he was bound and shackled,

With these three behaviors,
commoners would not befriend him,

However, Guan Zhong was released from his shackles,

united the feudal lords nine times,
and rectified the world.
If Guan Zhong had sacrificed his life
and disregarded the future,
how could he have achieved such dominance!
Nowadays, when rulers assess their ministers,
they do not consider their great achievements,

thus missing out on many talented individuals.
Therefore, a person of great virtue
does not have their minor flaws scrutinized;
a person of great reputation
does not have their small mistakes criticized.
A puddle left by a cow's hoof cannot breed sturgeons,
and a beehive cannot accommodate a swan's egg.
A small form is not enough to contain a large body.
Everyone has their shortcomings.
Everyone has their shortcomings.
If their overall direction is correct,
even if they have minor faults,
it is not enough to be a burden.
If their overall direction is wrong,
even if they have good conduct in their neighborhood,
it is not enough to be promoted.
Yan Zhuoju
was a great thief from Liangfu,
yet he became a loyal minister of Qi.
Duan Ganmu
was a great horse dealer in the Jin state,
yet he became the teacher of Marquis Wen.
Meng Mao married his sister-in-law

stabilizing its dangers
and resolving its problems.
Jing Yang
yet he commanded the respect of the feudal lords.
These four people
all had their shortcomings,
but their fame and achievements did not fade
because their overall direction was correct.
Ji Ai and Chen Zhongzi upheld their principles and resisted corrupt rulers,
refusing to enter the court of a despotic ruler
or eat the food of a chaotic world,
and eventually starved to death.
Why couldn't they adapt to the changing times and survive?
Because they focused on minor details and neglected the bigger picture.
Therefore, those who are overly cautious will not achieve great success,
those who are critical of others will not be tolerated by the masses,
those who are magnanimous are flexible in their principles,
and those who take big steps can reach far.
From ancient times to the present,
none of the Five Emperors and Three Kings
have been perfect in their conduct.
Therefore, the Book of Changes says:
"Small transgressions are passable, it is beneficial to be upright."
This means that everyone makes mistakes,
but we should not want them to be big.
Yao, Shun, Tang, and Wu were the most esteemed rulers;
Duke Huan of Qi and Duke Wen of Jin
were the most heroic of the Five Hegemons.
However, Yao had a reputation for being unloving,
Shun was accused of humiliating his father,
Tang and Wu had a history of exile and regicide,
and Wu Zixu plotted rebellion.
Therefore, a gentleman does not blame others,
he is upright but not harsh,
honest but not cutting,
knowledgeable but not arrogant,
both civil and military but not demanding.
When seeking help from others, he relies on their abilities;
when cultivating himself, he relies on morality.
To hold others accountable based on their abilities
is easy;
to cultivate oneself with morality
is difficult.
If it is difficult, then one's conduct will be noble;
if it is easy, then one will seek to be satisfied.
The jade of the Xia Dynasty cannot be without flaws,
the pearls of the bright moon cannot be without blemishes,
yet why does the world treasure them?
Because their minor flaws are not enough to detract from their great beauty.
Now, if we only focus on people's shortcomings
and forget their strengths,
it will be difficult to find worthy individuals in the world.
Baili Xi feeding cattle,
Yi Yin carrying a cauldron,
Jiang Ziya drumming a knife,
Ning Qi singing merchant songs,
all had their merits.
People saw their humble positions and dirty work,
but did not understand their great strategies,
and considered them unworthy.
When they became the Three Excellencies of the emperor
and established themselves as wise ministers of the feudal lords,
people finally believed in their extraordinary talents.
Those who emerged from the kitchen,
from the butcher's shop,
from the shackles of imprisonment,
from under the yoke of oxen,
were bathed
and cleansed with fire,
placed in the highest positions of the court,
relied upon as the Three Excellencies,
not ashamed before the nation,
not disgraced before the feudal lords,
their talents and positions perfectly aligned.
Therefore, only Yao knew Shun's worth before he accomplished anything;
after his achievements were established,
even the common people knew Shun's worth.
Therefore, if we abandon standards and seek talent in the court, the marketplace, or the wilderness,
we will surely miss many worthy individuals.
Why?
Because we can imitate the search,
but we do not know how to select the right people.
Things that resemble each other
are what confuse and bewilder rulers.
Things that are similar and resemble each other
are what dazzle and confuse the masses.
Therefore, the cruel may seem wise but are not truly wise,
the foolish may seem benevolent but are not truly benevolent,
and the simple-minded may seem brave but are not truly brave.
If the differences between people
were as clear as the difference between jade and stone,
or between mallow and amaranth,
then judging people would be easy.
But those who confuse people
are like mixing ligusticum with grain seedlings,
or snake gourd with deer fern.
Therefore, among swordsmiths who may encounter swords resembling the Moye sword,
only Ou Ye can identify their true type.
Among jade craftsmen who are dazzled by jade resembling Bilu jade,
only Yidun does not lose his discernment.
When a foolish ruler is confused by treacherous ministers and petty individuals who cast doubt on the noble,
only a sage can see through the subtle and discern the truth.
Therefore, when a snake raises its head a foot,
its overall length can be estimated.
By seeing an elephant's tusk,
its size can be discussed.
Xue Zhu and Yong Zi,
upon seeing a fox-like pattern on a sword,
can discern its sharpness or dullness.
Therefore, when sages evaluate worthiness,
they observe a single action and distinguish between the worthy and the unworthy.
Confucius declined the position of magistrate in Linqiu
and never resorted to stealing even a knife or hook.
Xu You declined the offer to be emperor
and never sought the benefits of being a marquis.
Therefore, those who have never been burned but still dare not touch fire
have seen its potential to burn.
Those who have never been injured but still dare not hold a knife
have seen its potential to harm.
From this perspective,
what is seen can be used to discuss what has not yet happened,
and observing minor details is sufficient to understand the overall picture.
Therefore, the way to judge a person
is to observe their actions when they are honored,
their generosity when they are wealthy,
their integrity when they are poor,
their principles when they are lowly,
and their contentment when they are impoverished.
Observe their response to adversity
to know their courage.
Observe their behavior in times of joy
to know their self-control.
Entrust them with wealth
to assess their benevolence.
Test them with fear
to know their integrity.
Then, one can fully understand human nature.
In ancient times, those who were good at rewarding
spent little but encouraged many.
Those who were good at punishing
used few punishments but prohibited evil.
Those who were good at giving
used little but gained virtue.
Those who were good at taking
gained much but caused no resentment.
Duke Xiang of Zhao was besieged in Jinyang,
and when the siege was lifted, he rewarded five people with merit,
with Gao He being the first to be rewarded.
His attendants said,
"During the crisis in Jinyang,
He did not have any great merit,
yet now he is the first to be rewarded,
why is that?"
Duke Xiang replied,
"During the siege of Jinyang,
my ancestral temples were in danger,
the state was in peril,
and all the officials had arrogant and disrespectful hearts,
but only He did not lose the etiquette of a ruler and minister."
Therefore, by rewarding one person,
all the ministers in the world
will be loyal to their ruler.
This is rewarding the few and encouraging the many.
King Wei of Qi set up a great cauldron in the courtyard and

reach my ears daily.
But observing your deeds,
the fields are overgrown,
the granaries are empty,

He then had Wu Yan boiled alive.
For thirty-two years after this, nothing was left unclaimed on the roads of Qi.
This is an example of punishment being minimal yet effectively deterring crime.

A year later,

Therefore, the sage encourages good deeds by capitalizing on what the people like,

Thus, by rewarding one person, the entire realm praises him,

Confucius executed Shao Zhengmao, and the evil in the state of Lu was stopped.
Zichan executed Deng Xi, and the wickedness in the state of Zheng was prohibited.
From the near, one can infer the far;
from the small, one can know the great.
Therefore, the sage governs a vast realm by adhering to simple principles.
This is what is meant by this.
Nothing in the world is easier than doing good,

What is called doing good
is being tranquil and inactive;
what is called doing evil
is being restless and full of desires.
When one satisfies one's true feelings and rejects excess,

follows one's nature and preserves one's authenticity,

Scaling city walls,
crossing dangerous passes,
forging tallies,

The reason why people today commit crimes

s because their desires are insatiable

The laws of the land state:

The laws and decrees expose their wickedness,
and the officials track their traces.
Even the most foolish men and women
know that there is no escape from wrongdoing

However, incompetent individuals cannot overcome their desires,
and they incur the death penalty
and the shame of punishment.
After the autumnal equinox,
the officials responsible for executions are constantly at the door,
and the blood of those executed flows in the streets.
Why is this so?
They are deluded by the prospect of gaining wealth
and blinded to the danger of death.
Now, when two armies

This is abandoning the fear of death and embracing certain death.
Therefore, the reversal of benefit and harm,
and the succession of misfortune and fortune,
must be carefully considered.
Sometimes, what one desires

what one avoids

People's desires
are similar to this.

During a busy market day,
he grabbed the gold and ran.
When asked

When one's mind is set on desire,
one forgets the consequences.
Therefore, the sage carefully observes the changes between movement and stillness,

He manages the emotions of like and dislike,

then troubles will not arise;
when giving and receiving are appropriate,
then offenses will not accumulate;
when like and dislike are managed,
then worries will not approach;
when joy and anger are harmonized,

nor do they reject blessings.

They are always full but not overflowing,

The human heart is similar to this.
If one measures oneself with the principles of the Dao,
having enough food to fill the stomach

If one does not measure oneself with the principles of the Dao and practices self-restraint,
even the power of ten thousand chariots is not enough to bring honor,
and the wealth of the world is not enough to bring joy.
Sun Shuao resigned from the position of Prime Minister three times without showing any worry,

Jing Ke's determination was not shaken when two dragons wrapped around his boat,

The sage's heart is peaceful, his will is easily contented,

Nothing can confuse him.

doors,
brooms,
mortars, and pestles,

cannot be forgotten,

Now that I am in trouble,

Your advice

He knew how to escape from trouble,

e knew how to hide wealth for a future marriage,

The value of the Heavenly Dao

Hibernating insects and birds' nests

If the emperor can truly embrace the Dao
and unite with the ultimate harmony,
then birds, beasts, grass, and trees will all benefit from his grace,
